prior_works.title: On the resemblance and containment of documents
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The paper generalizes Broder’s discrete set-containment retrieval objective to embedding-based soft containment, motivating the need for an LSH analogue that respects containment-like asymmetry rather than symmetric similarity.

prior_works.title: Improved Consistent Sampling, Weighted Minhash and L1 Sketching
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Ioffe’s weighted MinHash shows how to hash ‘soft’ set membership (weights) for containment-like tasks; the present work extends this line from weighted counts to embedding-driven hinge/dominance, highlighting why weighted Jaccard is insufficient and motivating a new similarity tailored to soft containment.

prior_works.title: Asymmetric LSH (ALSH) for Sublinear Time Maximum Inner Product Search (MIPS)
prior_works.role: Asymmetric transformations to enable LSH on inherently asymmetric objectives
prior_works.relationship_sentence: ALSH established that asymmetric retrieval goals can be addressed by transforming the space to fit LSH; the authors adopt this asymmetric perspective and design a dominance similarity for hinge/dominance containment, but derive a different (Fourier-based) hashing mechanism suited to their objective rather than MIPS.

prior_works.title: Locality-sensitive hashing scheme based on p-stable distributions
prior_works.authors: Mayur Datar, Nicole Immorlica, Piotr Indyk, Vahab S. Mirrokni
prior_works.role: Fourier/characteristic-function based LSH construction for Lp metrics
prior_works.relationship_sentence: This work’s use of distributional Fourier properties to craft LSH families informs the paper’s key step of moving hinge/dominance similarity into the frequency domain, enabling collision probabilities that track the proposed dominance similarity.

prior_works.title: Random Features for Large-Scale Kernel Machines
prior_works.role: Fourier-based random features for approximating kernels (Bochner’s theorem)
prior_works.relationship_sentence: By expressing dominance similarity via a Fourier transform, the authors can approximate it with random Fourier features, directly leveraging Rahimi–Recht to obtain trainable, data-sensitive projections compatible with fast hashing.

prior_works.title: Kernelized Locality-Sensitive Hashing
prior_works.role: Turning kernel similarities into LSH via Fourier-style embeddings
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The paper builds on the idea that kernel similarities can be hashed by operating in an implicit Fourier feature space; their dominance similarity is mapped into such a space to produce practical LSH for soft containment.

prior_works.title: Locality-Sensitive Binary Codes from Shift-Invariant Kernels
prior_works.role: Frequency-domain binary hashing for kernel similarities
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Their cosine/phase quantization of Fourier features into binary codes provides a template for the paper’s frequency-domain binarization, enabling efficient hash codes that preserve the proposed dominance similarity.

synthesis_narrative:
The paper’s core innovation—an LSHable similarity for soft set containment built from hinge distance and realized in the Fourier domain—sits at the intersection of set-containment hashing and Fourier-based kernel hashing. Broder’s MinHash framed containment retrieval as a hashing problem, and Ioffe’s weighted MinHash extended it to soft counts, but both fall short for embedding-driven soft containment with hinge/dominance behavior. Shrivastava and Li’s ALSH contributed the key conceptual turn: asymmetric retrieval objectives can be accommodated by crafting asymmetric similarities or transformations. The authors adopt this stance by introducing a dominance similarity tailored to hinge distance, rather than adapting to inner products.
To make this similarity LSH-friendly, the work leverages the Fourier/characteristic-function route pioneered by Datar et al. for p-stable LSH: express the target similarity via its spectral representation so that hash collision probabilities align with the desired measure. Rahimi and Recht’s Random Fourier Features then provide a practical vehicle to approximate the resulting kernel, yielding data-sensitive, trainable projections. Building on Kulis and Grauman’s kernelized LSH and Raginsky–Lazebnik’s shift-invariant kernel hashing, the authors quantize these Fourier features into binary hashes that preserve dominance similarity. Together, these threads—containment-oriented hashing, asymmetric LSH design, and Fourier-based kernel hashing—directly enable an index that is both theoretically grounded and practically efficient for soft set containment under hinge/dominance scoring.
